Award.AwardTitle: Working with Middle School Science Teachers to Design and Implement an Interactive Data Dashboard

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The William Marsh Rice University project will work with middle school science teachers to design, field-test, refine, and evaluate a set of data management tools that will be embedded in a web-based science curriculum. The project helps middle school science teachers monitor their students' progress, plan lessons, and reflect on their lessons. The project consists of three primary phases: first, the researchers will work with teachers to develop an initial set of data tools; second, teachers will test these tools in their classroom to verify that they are feasible and usable; and third, a pilot study will be conducted to examine how the tools are implemented in the classroom and an external evaluation will determine the early impact of the tools. As part of this study, the research team will work with 125 middle school science teachers across three different school districts. Ultimately, the findings from this project will identify characteristics of data management tools that are more likely to be used effectively by teachers and have a positive impact on science teaching and learning.

The project is employing a mixed methods design. Through design-based research, this project will help fill the need for research-based and teacher-driven design of online student management systems. During the first two years of the study, work will alternate between design/development and data collection, allowing the research team to collect and then incorporate teacher feedback into the tools' design. During these first two years, data will be collected through teacher surveys, interviews, and observations. The culmination of the project will be a one-year pilot, which will allow the research team to study the implementation of the final tools, and an independent evaluator from the University of Houston to evaluate the early impact of the tools on teaching practices and student achievement. The development and research proposed in this project will benefit teachers and students throughout the United States by improving what data teachers see about their students' progress in science and their own use of the curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original goal in this project was to design, field-test, and evaluate a set of data management tools that will provide middle school science teachers with the information they need to monitor their students' progress, plan lessons, reflect on their practice, and collaborate with other teachers. Involving end users as part of the design process is critical for ensuring that data dashboard options and functionality are aligned with teachers' daily needs, helping them in their teaching practices. Our findings shed light on ways for improving science instruction in middle schools.

The sample of participants in this study encompassed a diverse group of teachers (seventy three, grades 5-8) and nine instructional coaches with a variety of years of experience, degree of training received, and type of school taught (public and charter school districts). Despite high use of the digital curriculum reported by teachers, students typically had very low or no access, one of the major reasons was the lack of access to computers by students. This is an issue that limits students benefiting from new technological and digital resources.

An unexpected finding in this study was that nearly one fifth to one third of the teachers were not aware of the data tools offered by the curriculum (with the exception of the lesson planner). A major problem in accessing these tools was the difficulties associated with importing students rosters from a centralized district system. Lack of technology in the classroom allowed us to observe two important lesson planning practices. First, over half of teachers planned their lessons using pen and paper, and relied on paper-based resources. Second, in more "digital" classrooms, teachers use computers and maintained many of their planning resources in digital form, assigning on-line activities to their students on a regular basis.

Teachers' ideal digital tool should meet all of their planning and teaching needs in science. Regarding content, teachers cited short videos, lab videos, and interactive games and simulations as the most desired resources. The three most common changes regarding their ideal vision of teaching and assessment were more hands-on activities and labs, more field trips and other experiences that would make the science real and relevant to the children. In terms of how teachers want to assess their students, teachers suggested: more writing, oral presentations, and rubric-based assessment of student projects and hands-on labs.

From the instructional coaches perspective, they are more interested in data that helped them understand "the big picture." For example, the way in which students were learning so they could help teachers improve their instruction and form groups for tutorials or other interventions. Useful data to support them included previous years' state scores, district, benchmark or common assessment data, or other standardized assessments. Teachers, although making good use of summative evaluation data, needed to improve their use of formative assessments (even informal, such as class observations or exit tickets).

Though many potential recommendations emerged from our interviews and observations, we selected the following four tools for the dashboard, which can be generalized to other science curricula:

1. An annotation tool for allowing teachers to take notes on students and lessons, making them available in subsequent years in order to observe students' learning trajectories. Teachers want to keep anecdotal records and observations on their students as valuable formative data. For example teachers will be able to capture their thoughts on lessons, their observations of students, and to retain and access all of that information easily.
